awd_titl_txt: Network Comparison, a Cornerstone of the Foundations of Network Science
awd_abstract_narration:
"Big data" increasingly means big networks, because such data either directly concerns relational structures as in human and animal mobility patterns, gene interaction networks, or is influenced by an underlying relational structure as in epidemiological studies, urban studies, and cultural diffusion. Most applications of networks rely crucially on comparing networks, for example to detect changes in one network across time, to categorize or classify multiple networks of similar types, or to build analogies across fields by comparing networks of different origins. The question of how to compare two networks in a principled way, without relying on the ad hoc choice of statistics used by many current comparison methods, is key to the foundations of network science. This project will bring to bear new ideas from mathematics, computer science, and statistical physics on the problem of principled, structural comparison of networks. Through pre-existing collaborations, the PIs will leverage these new comparison methods to address questions in several different areas, for example, about: how food webs change across gradients like latitude, altitude, and temperature,morphological growth patterns of bacterial colonies, the evolution of human culture and communities, and links between socio-economic indicators and epidemiology.


Our project will develop new rigorous and principled methods of comparing the structure of complex networks. The methods to be pursued aim to get away from single-scale summary statistics; to break new ground, we must think in terms of structural distance rather than statistical inference. In combination with tools from machine learning, such structural comparison methods are an important step towards defining the "space of real-world networks", which could serve as a more rigorous basis for a theory of complex networks. These methods have four advantageous features: (1) they systematically consider multiple scales of network organization, (2) they do not depend on an identification of the nodes of the two networks beforehand, (3) they can compare networks of different sizes, and (4) they are not dependent on any particular generative model of network growth. Very few, if any, of the existing network comparison methods have all of these features, and those that do exist have not been extensively developed. These features enable many new applications in a range of areas, including ecology, microbiology, cultural evolution, and epidemiology.

por.por_cntn:
The major objective of this project was to develop new tools for network comparison to answer questions such as "How different is a power grid from a social network?" While the question can seem vague, network structures of all kinds are described as graphs: mathematical constructs that we should be able to construct.

Our approach was two-fold. First, develop a network compression, or network description, method. This means we need to find a set of structural metrics that describe a network well, are easy to measure and can be mapped to connection rules to allow network reconstruction. Second, compare networks by comparing their compressed counterpart; either by directly comparing the output of the structural metrics, or by comparing the ensemble of reconstructed networks.

In the first arm of our approach, we developed a metric called the Onion Decomposition.This metric is calculated by an algorithm which peels away nodes of a network layer by layer, starting from the least central to the most central layers. This metric, unlike previous centrality metric, allows exact reconstruction rules such that we can build random networks by specifying, for every node, their degree (number of connections) and onion layer (their centrality) and even degree or layer correlations among neighbors. In applications of this work, we have shown the importance of onion layers to help predict information silos in social networks, localized outbreaks of infectious diseases in contact networks, and more. The metric itself is therefore incredibly useful. The algorithm is easy to run and its source code is open and freely available.

In the second arm of our approach, we reviewed existing methods for network comparisons and implemented dozens of them as part of a freely available software. This allowed us to list the known strengths and weaknesses of existing approach. Building on this list, we then proposed our own method for network comparison: A nested series of statistical comparison based on the different level of information contained in the onion decomposition of a network. With a single line of code, one can now obtain a series of number describing the statistical distance (or divergence, a number between 0 and 1) describing the difference in connectivity, correlations and layered structure of the two networks.

We describe the resulting framework as principled because unlike other network analysis metric based on centrality, and unlike other network comparison approach, ours allow the reconstruction of networks and its mathematical description within models. This is why along with the theoretical and software products offered by our project, we list numerous applications including the Zika epidemic, descriptions of information silos, the social reinforcement phenomenon, and compression of temporal networks or cellular automata.

Altogether, this project has provided new algorithms for network analysis, new mathematical frameworks to describe the structure and dynamics of networks, a review of existing network comparison approach. Building on all of this, we finally proposed new statistical methods filling existing gaps in our network science toolbox around the description, compression, reconstruction, and comparison of network structures.
